LOGIC-LM is a novel framework that integrates Large Language Models (LLMs) with symbolic solvers to improve logical problem-solving. The framework decomposes a logical reasoning problem into three stages: Problem Formulation, Symbolic Reasoning, and Result Interpretation. 

![Problem formulation stage illustration](image4)


In the Problem Formulation stage, an LLM converts the natural language description of the problem into an appropriate symbolic formulation, identifying key entities, facts, and rules present in the problem statement. The formulation is then used by a deterministic symbolic solver to perform inference and obtain a symbolic-represented answer. 

![Symbolic reasoning stage illustration](image5)


Our method first utilizes LLMs to translate a natural language problem into a symbolic formulation. Afterward, a deterministic symbolic solver performs inference on the formulated problem. We also introduce a self-refinement module, which utilizes the symbolic solver’s error messages to revise symbolic formulations.

As shown in Table 1, the LOGIC-LM framework significantly improves performance over pure LLMs and chain-of-thought prompting techniques. For example, on the PrOntoQA dataset, LOGIC-LM achieves a 98.79% accuracy, while the standard CoT method achieves only 67.80%.

| Dataset | Standard CoT | LOGIC-LM |
| --- | --- | --- |
| PrOntoQA | 67.80 | 98.79 |
| ProofWriter | 49.17 | 68.11 |
| FOLIO | 57.35 | 70.58 |
| LogicalDeduction | 42.33 | 75.25 |
| AR-LSAT | 17.31 | 35.06 |

This result demonstrates the effectiveness of the LOGIC-LM framework in solving logical reasoning problems. The framework's ability to combine the strengths of LLMs and symbolic solvers makes it a promising avenue for faithful logical reasoning.

Conclusion:
The LOGIC-LM model solves a problem using its modules by first formulating the problem in symbolic language using a Large Language Model (LLM), then performing inference on the formulated problem using a deterministic symbolic solver, and finally interpreting the output to obtain the final answer.

In the development of multi-hop question answering (QA) datasets, the characteristics of the data can significantly impact the performance of QA models. Here are some differences in candidate and document statistics between WikiHop and MedHop datasets:
 
![average # candidates in WikiHop and MedHop](image4)
 
WikiHop has a more diverse number of candidates per sample, ranging from 2 to 79, with an average of 19.8. In contrast, MedHop has a more consistent number of candidates per sample, with the majority having 9 candidates, due to the way documents are selected up until a maximum of 64 documents is reached. 
 

![max and average # docs in WikiHop and MedHop](image4)
 
WikiHop has a smaller average number of documents per sample, ranging from 3 to 63, with an average of 13.7. MedHop, on the other hand, has a significantly larger average number of documents per sample, ranging from 5 to 64, with an average of 29. This can lead to potential computational infeasibility for a majority of existing RC models.

These differences in candidate and document statistics can make WikiHop and MedHop challenging for QA models in different ways. WikiHop's diverse number of candidates and smaller number of documents may require models to be more flexible and adapt to various question types. In contrast, MedHop's consistent number of candidates and larger number of documents may require models to be more efficient in handling a large amount of information and navigating complex document paths.

Therefore, the answer to the question is that the candidate and document statistics differ between WikiHop and MedHop datasets, with WikiHop having a more diverse number of candidates and smaller number of documents, and MedHop having a more consistent number of candidates and larger number of documents.

According to Figure 5, the first step of cold start is **Prompting ChatGPT solely through system messages and visual annotations, employing a heuristic approach**. This stage concludes only when satisfactory in-context examples are identified.

![Step 1 Prompt](image5) 

[5] We present Sythus, an automated pipeline for generating high-quality instruction-response pairs in multiple languages. Building upon the framework proposed by LLaVA [28], we utilize ChatGPT to generate instruction-response pairs based on visual content. To ensure the quality of the generated instruction-response pairs, our pipeline incorporates system messages, visual annotations, and in-context examples as prompts for ChatGPT. System messages define the desired tone and style of the generated instruction-response pairs, while visual annotations provide essential image information such as bounding boxes and image descriptions. In-context examples assist ChatGPT in learning within the context. Since the quality of coreset impacts subsequent data collection process [10], we employ a cold-start strategy to enhance in-context examples before the large-scale query. During the cold-start stage, in-context examples are collected by prompting ChatGPT solely through system messages and visual annotations, employing a heuristic approach. This stage concludes only when satisfactory in-context examples are identified. In step 4, once the instruction-response pairs are obtained, the pipeline expands them into Chinese (zh), Japanese (ja), Spanish (es), German (de), French (fr), Korean (ko), and Arabic (ar). For further details, please refer to Appendix C, and task-specific prompts can be found in Appendix D.

[10] The ability to learn from large unlabeled corpora has allowed neural language models to advance the frontier in natural language understanding. However, existing self-supervision techniques operate at the word  form  level, which serves as a surrogate for the underlying semantic content. This paper proposes a method to employ weak-supervision directly at the word  sense  level. Our model, named SenseBERT, is pre-trained to predict not only the masked words but also their WordNet supersenses. Accordingly, we attain a lexical-semantic level language model, without the use of human annotation. SenseBERT achieves significantly improved lexical understanding, as we demonstrate by experimenting on SemEval Word Sense Disambiguation, and by attaining a state of the art result on the ‘Word in Context’ task.

Therefore, SenseBERT outperforms other models on the Word in Context task, achieving a state of the art result with a score of 72.1.

We automatically extract paragraphs which contain a parallel sentence from articles on the same topic in each language ([5]). This is the first step in the MLQA annotation pipeline.

The process begins with automatically identifying sentences from Wikipedia articles which have the same or similar meaning in multiple languages, as shown in Figure 1. The parallel sentences are then extracted from the articles.

![Extract parallel sentence with surrounding context](image4)

We define two tasks to assess performance on MLQA: cross-lingual transfer (XLT) and generalised cross-lingual transfer (G-XLT) ([7]). These tasks require models to transfer knowledge from one language to another, which is a challenging task due to the differences in languages and cultural contexts.

The first step in the MLQA annotation pipeline is to automatically extract parallel sentences from articles on the same topic in each language. This allows us to create a large-scale multilingual dataset for training and evaluating QA models.

**Answer:** The first step in the MLQA annotation pipeline is to automatically extract parallel sentences from articles on the same topic in each language.

We first look at the general performance of the EN-TAG system in French compared to the EN system, as shown in [2] In this work, we experimented with the incorporation of speaker-gender tags during the training of NMT systems in order to improve morphological agreement. We focused particularly on language pairs that express grammatical gender but included other language pairs as well, as linguistic studies have shown that the style and syntax of language used by males and females differs (Coates, 2015).

As illustrated in `![Morphological Agreement](image2)`, the EN-TAG system achieves a higher BLEU score than the EN system for French, with a score of 39.26 compared to 37.82. This indicates that the EN-TAG system has better morphological agreement than the EN system.

As shown in `![French Test Sets](image3)`, the EN-TAG system performs well on the male-only test set (FR (M)) with a score of 38.71*, and even better on the female-only test set (FR (F)) with a score of 38.97*. In conclusion, the EN-TAG system performs better than the EN system for different test sets in French, indicating that the incorporation of speaker-gender tags can lead to significant improvements in morphological agreement and overall performance.

**Modeling Complexity of Language with Word and Character Embeddings**
===========================================================

Language is a complex phenomenon with many nuances, making it challenging for models to capture its intricacies. To address this, our model utilizes both word-level and character-level embeddings as inputs. The hierarchical CRF model, as described in [1], consists of three components: a character-level neural network, a word-level neural network, and a linear-chain CRF layer. Each component plays a crucial role in capturing the complexity of language.

**Character-Level Embeddings**
-----------------------------

Character-level embeddings, such as those used in the character-level Bi-LSTM (as shown in image5![CRF Layer: capturing both word and character information](image5)), capture morphological variations, capitalization patterns, and other subword information. This is particularly useful for languages with complex grammar and morphology, such as those with many inflectional endings. By incorporating character-level embeddings, our model can better capture the nuances of language and improve its performance.

**Word-Level Embeddings**
-------------------------

Word-level embeddings, on the other hand, capture the semantic meaning of words and their relationships with other words. These embeddings are typically learned through neural networks, such as RNNs or CNNs, and are used to produce context-sensitive hidden representations for each word. By combining word-level and character-level embeddings, our model can capture both the semantic meaning of words and their morphological properties.

**Why Both Word-Level and Character-Level Embeddings?**
----------------------------------------------------

The use of both word-level and character-level embeddings as inputs allows our model to capture the complex interactions between words and their subword components. By considering both the semantic meaning of words and their morphological properties, our model can better understand the nuances of language and improve its performance on tasks such as NER. This is particularly important for low-resource languages, where parallel corpora and dictionaries may be scarce.

**Experimental Evidence**
-------------------------

Our experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of using both word-level and character-level embeddings as inputs. As shown in image4![Model: combining word and character embeddings](image4), our model achieves state-of-the-art or competitive NER performance on commonly tested languages under a cross-lingual setting, with much lower resource requirements than past approaches.

**Conclusion**
----------

In conclusion, our model uses both word-level and character-level embeddings as inputs to capture the complex interactions between words and their subword components. By combining these embeddings, our model can better understand the nuances of language and improve its performance on tasks such as NER. This approach is particularly useful for low-resource languages, where parallel corpora and dictionaries may be scarce.

The accuracy of the discriminator for the relation type /people/person/place_lived shows a critical point of decline at epoch 7 as seen in Figure 3.![ Critical point of decline for relation type /people/person/place_lived ](image3)

We can see from the description of the image, at epoch 7 the discriminator's accuracy for the relation type /people/person/place_lived has reached a critical point of decline. 

[3] discriminator performs well on    $N^{D}$  ; moreover,  $N^{D}$    is not used during adversarial training. Therefore, the accuracy on    $N^{D}$    is the criterion to reﬂect the performance of the discriminator. In the early epochs, the generated samples from the generator increases the accuracy, because it has not possessed the ability of challenging the discriminator; however, as the training epoch increases, this accuracy gradually decreases, which means the discriminator becomes weaker. It is because the generator gradually learn to generate more accurate true positive samples in each bag. After the proposed adversarial learning process, the generator is strong enough to collapse the discriminator. Figure  4  gives more intuitive display of the trend of accuracy. Note that there is a critical point of the decline of accuracy for each presented relation types. It is because that the chance we give the generator to challenge the discriminator is just one time scanning of the noisy dataset; this critical point is yielded when the generator has already been robust enough. Thus, we stop the training process when the model reaches this critical point. 

Thus, the answer to the user question is that the accuracy of the discriminator for the relation type /people/person/place_lived shows a critical point of decline at epoch 7.

We have presented an outline of the current research related to computational detection of semantic shifts using diachronic (temporal) word embeddings [1]. The key milestones in tracing diachronic semantic shifts include the work by Kim et al. [7] in 2014, who employed prediction-based word embedding models to trace diachronic semantic shifts, and the release of the Google Books Ngrams corpus [9] in 2011, which spurred work on the new discipline of ‘culturomics’ and the study of human culture through digital media.

Figure 1 shows the timeline of events that have been influential in the development of research in this area [1]. ![Key Milestones 2011-2014](image1)  Introduced in 2011, Google Books Ngrams corpus is a pivotal dataset that has driven significant research on diachronic semantic shifts [9]. The first key milestone is the work by Kim et al. [7] in 2014, who used prediction-based word embedding models to trace diachronic semantic shifts. This research was built upon by Hamilton et al. [8] in 2016, who showed the superiority of SGNS over explicit PPMI-based distributional models in semantic shifts analysis.

In addition to these research papers, another milestone is the release of the yearly text collection, the New-York Times Annotated Corpus (Sandhaus, 2008), which has been used to trace subtle semantic shifts [10].![NYT Annotated Corpus](image2) This corpus has been employed by several researchers to study diachronic semantic shifts, including Zhang et al. [10] and Szymanski [10].

Conclusively, the key milestones in tracing diachronic semantic shifts from 2010 to 2017 include the work by Kim et al. [7] in 2014, the release of the Google Books Ngrams corpus [9] in 2011, and the use of the New-York Times Annotated Corpus [10] in 2015 and 2016.

### Filtering Process Overview
The main steps in the filtering process for collecting images in the entity dataset include cross-referencing each entity entry with its corresponding Wikipedia page, removing entities without valid Wikipedia pages, sourcing images from Creative Commons (CC) and then filtering out entities with insufficient images via Google Image Search. 

### Image1: The Filtering Process 
![Word Embedding Layer](image1)
The filtering process begins with a word embedding layer that aids in the embedding of entities into a format that can be processed by models. Next, retrieval is performed, and augmentation of information follows, enabling the process to refine its understanding of entities. 

### Step 1: Entity Wikipedia Cross-Reference 
The comprehensive list of entities is cross-referenced with its corresponding Wikipedia page. This step is crucial as it ensures the accuracy and relevance of the entities selected for the dataset. 

### Step 2: Entity Image Sourcing and Filtering 
Entities lacking valid Wikipedia pages are removed from the list. This step eliminates entities that may not have enough information or may not be relevant for the dataset. Subsequently, images are sourced from Creative Commons (CC), and further filtering is conducted by removing entities that don’t have a sufficient number of images obtained via Google Image Search engine. 

### Step 3: Database Collection 
The collected metadata is stored in a CSV file containing essential information such as image URLs, source page URLs, renamed image names, and the corresponding Wikipedia page URLs. After filtering, the final number of entities in the SnapNTell dataset is 7,568. 

### Conclusion 
The steps outlined above are the main components of the filtering process for collecting images in the entity dataset. Each step is designed to refine and improve the quality and relevance of the entities and their corresponding images, ultimately leading to a more accurate and comprehensive dataset.

**Analyzing the Impact of Features on SPECTER Performance**
====================================================================

To better understand how the inclusion or exclusion of specific features affects the performance of the SPECTER model, we need to examine the results presented in [10]. Ablation studies were conducted to investigate the effect of removing or adding different metadata fields from the input to SPECTER.

### Removing or Adding Metadata Fields

The results of the ablation study are shown in Table 2. Specifically, removing the abstract from the textual input and relying only on the title results in a substantial decrease in performance. This suggests that the abstract plays a crucial role in the SPECTER model's ability to accurately represent documents.

![Removing abstract hurts performance](image4)!{Removing abstract hurts performance}(image4)

On the other hand, adding authors as an input field actually hurts performance. This may be due to the fact that author names are sparse in the corpus, making it difficult for the model to infer document-level relatedness from them.

![Adding authors hurts performance](image4)!{Adding authors hurts performance}(image4)

Interestingly, adding venues as an input field also slightly decreases performance, except on document classification tasks.

![Adding venues hurts performance](image4)!{Adding venues hurts performance}(image4)

These results highlight the importance of carefully selecting the input features for the SPECTER model to achieve optimal performance.

### Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------------

The inclusion or exclusion of specific features has a significant impact on the performance of the SPECTER model across different tasks. By understanding the effects of removing or adding metadata fields, we can better design the input features for the SPECTER model to achieve optimal performance. The results of this ablation study provide valuable insights into the importance of the abstract, authors, and venues in the SPECTER model's ability to accurately represent documents.

**Answer:** The inclusion or exclusion of specific features has a significant impact on the performance of the SPECTER model, with the removal of the abstract resulting in a substantial decrease in performance, and the addition of authors or venues slightly decreasing performance, except on document classification tasks.

### Improving Performance with Step-Back Prompting and RAG

Step-Back prompting in combination with Retrieval Augmentation Generation (RAG) is demonstrated to be a highly effective method for improving model performance on challenging tasks. As shown in [7], when used on the TimeQA task, the combination of Step-Back and RAG achieves a remarkable accuracy of 68.7%, significantly outperforming other methods.

#### Improving Multi-Hop Reasoning Tasks

On the MuSiQue and StrategyQA benchmarks, which are challenging multi-hop reasoning tasks, the addition of Step-Back prompting to RAG demonstrates the ability to improve model performance substantially. As seen in [9], the performance of PaLM-2L and GPT-4 on MuSiQue and StrategyQA is significantly improved when using Step-Back prompting with RAG, outperforming other methods.

- **MuSiQue**: Step-Back + RAG achieves an accuracy of 42.8%, outperforming GPT-4 and other prompting methods.
- **StrategyQA**: Step-Back + RAG achieves an accuracy of 86.4%, significantly outperforming other methods.

### Ablation Study

An ablation study conducted in [3] shows the robustness of Step-Back prompting against the number of exemplars used in demonstration. This suggests that the sample efficiency of learning abstraction skills is key to the success of Step-Back prompting.

### Few-Shot Ablation

In [5], an analysis of the effects of Step-Back prompting on model performance indicates that it is capable of correcting 15.4% of wrong predictions made by the base model and introduces errors only 4.4% of the time.

Given the user question, we need to compare the collapsed tree and tree traversal querying methods in terms of F1 score across different context lengths.

As [5] mentions, the collapsed tree approach offers a simpler way to search for relevant information by considering all nodes in the tree simultaneously, as depicted in![Collapsed Tree Approach](image3). Instead of going layer-by-layer, this method flattens the multi-layered tree into a single layer, essentially bringing all the nodes onto the same level for comparison.

On the other hand, the tree traversal method first selects the top-k most relevant root nodes based on their cosine similarity to the query embedding, as described in [8]. The children of these selected nodes are considered at the next layer and the top-k nodes are selected from this pool again based on their cosine similarity to the query vector. This process is repeated until we reach the leaf nodes. 

To compare the performance of both methods, we need to refer to the experiment results in [6]. Figure![Comparison of Collapsed Tree and Tree Traversal](image4) shows the performance of tree traversal with different top-sizes and collapsed tree with different maximum token numbers. The collapsed tree approach consistently performs better.

To further understand the performance of both methods, we can refer to the qualitative analysis in [7]. RAPTOR’s tree-based retrieval allows it to choose nodes from different tree layers, matching the question’s detail level. This approach often yields more relevant and comprehensive information for downstream tasks than DPR.

In terms of F1 score, the collapsed tree approach consistently outperforms the tree traversal method across different context lengths. For example, as shown in![Model Performance Comparison](image1), the collapsed tree approach achieves a higher F1 score than the tree traversal method in the Longformer-base model.

Therefore, the answer to the user question is: The collapsed tree querying method outperforms the tree traversal method in terms of F1 score across different context lengths.

### QACHECK: Question-Guided Multi-hop Fact-Checking System
![image5 is described as: QACheck: Question-Guided Multi-hop Fact-Checking Demo](image5)

QACHECK is a multi-hop fact-checking system that guides the model's reasoning process by asking a series of questions critical for verifying a claim. It consists of five key modules: a claim verifier, a question generator, a question-answering module, a QA validator, and a reasoner.

### Example of Guided Reasoning Process
![image2 is described as: Claim: Sunlight can travel to the deepest part of the Black Sea. ¥v
Q1: What is the greatest depth » of the Black Sea? =
A1: Black sea has a maximum « depth of 2,212 meters. ¥
Q2: How far can sunlight » penetrate water?.
A2: Sunlight does not penetrate « water below 1,000 meters. ¥](image2)

The system starts by asking a question to gather more information about the claim. In this case, the question is "What is the greatest depth of the Black Sea?" The answer is then used to ask another question, "How far can sunlight penetrate water?" The final answer is obtained by analyzing the answers to both questions.

### Architecture of QACHECK
![image4 is described as: Claim = [@uNiy
We already know the following:
To verify the claim, what is the next question we need to know the answer to?](image4)

The architecture of QACHECK consists of five principal modules: a Claim Verifier, a Question Generator, a Question-Answering Model, a Validator, and a Reasoner. The system starts by verifying the claim using the Claim Verifier. If the claim is not verified, the system generates a question to gather more information about the claim. The Question-Answering Model is then used to answer the question. The Validator is used to validate the usefulness of the answer. If the answer is useful, it is added to the context. Otherwise, the system generates another question.

### Question-Guided Reasoning

Question-guided reasoning is a process of verifying a claim by asking a series of questions. The system starts by asking a question to gather more information about the claim. The answer is then used to ask another question. This process is repeated until the claim is verified or the system reaches the maximum allowed iterations.

### Evaluation Results
![image1 is described as: Claim = [@uNiy
We already know the following:
Can we know whether the claim is true or false now? Yes or no?](image1)

The evaluation results of QACHECK show that it achieves a macro-F1 score of 55.67, 54.67, and 52.35 on HOVER two-hop, three-hop, and four-hop claims, respectively. It also achieves a 59.47 F1 score on FEVEROUS. These scores are better than directly using Instruct GP T, Codex, or FLAN-T5. They are also on par with the systems that apply claim decomposition strategies, i.e., CoT, and ProgramFC.

**Conclusion**
QACHECK is a question-guided multi-hop fact-checking system that guides the model's reasoning process by asking a series of questions critical for verifying a claim. It achieves better evaluation results than existing systems and provides a transparent, explainable, and user-friendly fact-checking process.

The MMMU benchmark is comprehensive, covering a broad range of college-level multidiscipline multimodal understanding and reasoning, with 11.5K carefully selected multimodal questions, spanning six common disciplines, 30 diverse subjects, and 183 subfields. Unlike existing benchmarks, MMMU requires expert-level reasoning, including tasks that demand the processing of various heterogeneous image types and the integration of domain-specific knowledge to deeply understand both the text and images and to reason. The benchmark's unique challenges, such as diverse image formats and interleaved text-image inputs, make it more rigorous and demanding than current benchmarks.

![Comparison of MMMU with existing benchmarks in terms of dataset size, image types, and reasoning depth](image5)

Figure 4, detailed in the benchmark, highlights the differences between MMMU and prior benchmarks. From the breadth perspective, MMMU covers college-level knowledge with 30 image formats, including diagrams, tables, charts, chemical structures, photos, paintings, geometric shapes, music sheets, medical images, etc. In contrast, existing benchmarks focus on daily knowledge and common sense, with limited image formats.

To further distinguish the difference between MMMU and other existing ones, the benchmark details the challenge of diverse image formats. The benchmark requires LMMs to jointly understand the images and text, often recalling deep subject knowledge, and conducting complex reasoning based on the understanding and knowledge to reach a solution.

From the depth perspective, MMMU requires deliberate reasoning with college-level subject knowledge, whereas previous benchmarks require commonsense knowledge or simple physical or temporal reasoning. This complexity in depth is reflected in the benchmark's tasks, which demand expert-level reasoning, including tasks that require the application of "Fourier Transform" or "Equilibrium Theory" to derive the solution.

The MMMU benchmark underscores both the progress and the challenges in multimodal understanding and reasoning. While GPT-4V leads in performance, the overall results indicate substantial room for improvement, especially in domains with complex visual input and heavy reasoning with subject knowledge.

The benchmark features problems sourced from college exams, quizzes, and textbooks, spanning six common disciplines, with 11.5K carefully selected multimodal questions, covering 30 diverse subjects and 183 subfields. This broad range of questions and subjects makes MMMU a comprehensive benchmark for multimodal understanding and reasoning.

To answer the question: The MMMU benchmark stands out from existing benchmarks in terms of dataset size, image types, and reasoning depth, requiring expert-level reasoning and the integration of domain-specific knowledge to deeply understand both the text and images and to reason.

We note that the exclusion of different data sources, specifically the removal of crowdsourced examples, entity linking, and head word supervision, has varying effects on the model's performance on the Ultra-Fine category.

Table 4![Ultra-Fine performance drops to 52.9% F1](image1) shows the performance of our model on the development set for different type granularity and for different supervision data. When removing crowdsourced examples, entity linking, and head word supervision, the Ultra-Fine F1 score drops significantly to 32.8%, 23.1%, and 29.5% respectively.

In the results in Table 4, we see that crowdsourced examples are particularly helpful for predicting Ultra-Fine labels, with a F1 score of 58.1% when all supervision sources are available, but dropping to 28.6% when this source is removed. On the other hand, head word supervision is also beneficial, but to a lesser extent, with a F1 score of 45.5% when this source is available, but dropping to 35.6% when it is removed. Entity linking, while being useful for predicting Fine labels, does not seem to have a significant impact on Ultra-Fine label prediction.

Overall, the exclusion of different data sources results in a significant drop in the model's performance on the Ultra-Fine category.

Conclusively, the model's performance on the Ultra-Fine category is heavily reliant on the inclusion of crowdsourced examples and head word supervision.

Bergen is rich in history and art, featuring a wide variety of museums that showcase its cultural heritage. 
![Bryggen, a UNESCO World Heritage site](image1)! Bryggen, located in the heart of Bergen, is a UNESCO World Heritage site [6]. It features a collection of wooden buildings that date back to the 14th century, giving visitors a glimpse into the city's rich history. Guided tours are available, allowing visitors to explore the site in detail.
 
The Hanseatic Museum And Sch t stu ene is another UNESCO World Heritage site [5]. This museum provides a unique insight into the lives of the Hanseatic merchants who once lived and traded in Bergen. Visitors can explore the German merchants' assembly rooms and learn about the history of the city. The site also features a beautiful wooden building, the Sch t stu ene, which is a must-see for anyone interested in history and architecture.
 
Bryggen Museum is also located in the UNESCO World Heritage site of Bryggen [2]. This museum features a collection of artifacts and exhibits that tell the story of Bergen's history, from its founding to the present day. Visitors can learn about the city's role in the Hanseatic League and see a collection of ancient artifacts, including a well-preserved Viking boat.
 
UNESCO World Heritage sites are designated by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) for their cultural, natural, or mixed (both cultural and natural) significance. These sites are considered to be of outstanding value to humanity and are protected for future generations.
 
In conclusion, the museums associated with UNESCO World Heritage in Bergen are Bryggen, The Hanseatic Museum And Sch t stu ene, and Bryggen Museum.

Bergen offers a diverse range of tourist attractions that cater to various interests. For those interested in art and culture, Bergen Kunsthall [2] is a must-visit, featuring exhibitions and events by international artists. The museum has a unique collection of around 50 original wooden buildings that once stood in the centre of Bergen, showcasing the city's history and architecture [3]. 

![The reconstructed Bergen of the 19th and 20th centuries](image3)

Other notable attractions include the Bergen Aquarium [9], which houses a vast array of marine life, and the Fish Market [8], where visitors can sample local seafood delicacies and other specialities. The centre also has a wide range of activities for children, such as a play area and a cinema [9].

For outdoor enthusiasts, the Mount Fløyen cable car offers breathtaking views of the city, fjord, and ocean [5]. Visitors can also explore the Storeblå Aquaculture Visitor Centre, which provides insight into Norwegian aquaculture and features a bracing RIB boat trip to a fish farm outside Bergen [6].

![Ulriken Express Bus service to the cable car](image5)

Moreover, Bergen has a variety of shopping and activity centres, including Vestkanten, which offers a water park complex, a spa section, bowling, and many other activities [10]. 

![Vestkanten shopping and activity centre](image10)

Overall, Bergen's tourist attractions cater to different visitor interests, from art and culture to outdoor activities and shopping.

Bergen offers a variety of outdoor and indoor attractions that cater to different interests and age groups.

![Spectacular views of Bergen from the top of Mount Fløyen](image1)
The Fløibanen Funicular is a popular outdoor attraction that takes you to the top of Mount Fløyen, offering spectacular views of the city and its surroundings. At the top, you can enjoy nature trails, a playground, and a Trolls kogen forest (as described in [3]).

Vestkanten is the biggest shopping and activity centre in Norway, featuring a water park complex, a spa section, bowling, minigolf, skating, curling, shops, and restaurants (as mentioned in [2]). It's just 10 minutes from the centre of Bergen.

![A fun-filled day at Vestkanten](image2)

Bergen Aquarium is one of the biggest tourist attractions in Bergen, offering a fascinating experience with creatures from tropical rainforests, the foreshore, the ocean depths, and the Arctic (as described in [5]). You can see sea lions, penguins, otters, crocodiles, and many more animals, and enjoy a film in their cinema.

![A penguin at Bergen Aquarium](image3)

The Fish Market is the best-known and most visited outdoor market in Norway, situated in the heart of the city (as described in [4]). It sells a wide range of seafood delicacies, local specialities, and has an indoor part called Mathallen, which is open all year.

Bergen Climbing Park, Høyt & Lavt, is an indoor climbing park with lots of space for everyone to climb, from beginners to experienced climbers (as described in [7]). They offer ropes, auto-belay, bouldering, and a fitness room.

![Indoor climbing at Bergen Climbing Park](image4)

To find ecolabel tourism enterprises in the region, look for the in the Bergen Guide (as mentioned in [9]).

Bergen has over 60 different attractions, museums, and galleries, including the Hanseatic wharf Bryggen, Bergen Aquarium, the Fløibanen funicular, and the Fish Market (as described in [6]).

Some other attractions in Bergen include the Escape Bryggen, Magic Ice Bergen, Storeblå Aquaculture Visitor Centre, Ulriken643, and Bergen Science Centre – Vilvite.

Answer: Bergen offers a variety of outdoor and indoor attractions, including the Fløibanen Funicular, Vestkanten, Bergen Aquarium, The Fish Market, and Bergen Climbing Park, which provide a range of activities such as nature trails, water parks, animal exhibits, and indoor climbing.

Many museums in Bergen offer activities for children.![A child watching a model ship in a maritime museum](image5) As mentioned in [5], the Bergen Maritime Museum has family activities both outdoors and indoors, including a café with outdoor seating, rowing boat hire, loan of kayaks, and a vintage boat harbour. This suggests that children can engage in hands-on activities while learning about the sea and its history.

Additionally, the Oleana Économusée and the Osterøy Museum, as described in [3] and [6], offer a glimpse into the textile industry and local building customs, which might be of interest to children. The Oleana Économusée, in particular, is housed in a listed textile factory dating from 1859, where children can learn about the textile industry in Western Norway.

Regarding the museum that specifically focuses on educating about the history of leprosy, the Leprosy Museum St. George’s Hospital stands out. According to [2], this museum provides an in-depth look at leprosy, its widespread presence in the past, and the efforts made to eradicate the disease. It also tells the story of Gerhard Armauer Hansen’s discovery of the leprae bacillus in 1873.

In summary, the Bergen Maritime Museum, the Oleana Économusée, and the Osterøy Museum offer activities for children, while the Leprosy Museum St. George’s Hospital is the museum that specifically focuses on educating about the history of leprosy.

Several museums in Bergen showcase historical and cultural heritage. One of these is the Old Bergen Museum, a living museum with a collection of 50 original wooden buildings from the 19th and 20th centuries, along with an English-style park and a seawater pool [1].
 
The Bryggen area, a UNESCO World Heritage site, offers a unique experience of Bergen's history, starting at Bryggens Museum and taking visitors through the ruins of the city's first town hall, hidden below street level, and ending at the Schtstuene assembly rooms [3].
 
Osterøy Museum, located in a beautiful cultural landscape, shows how people lived in the countryside outside Bergen through old buildings, storytelling, and experiences, linking objects to the living cultural heritage of textiles and costumes [4].
 
Haakon's Hall, a 13th-century royal banqueting hall, is a living national cultural heritage site and provides an insight into what being a king was like in the Middle Ages [6].
 
![A view of Bergen's historic town centre, with the Old Bergen Museum in the foreground](image1)
 
![A reconstructed 19th-century wooden building at the Old Bergen Museum](image2)
 
![Bryggen's historic wooden buildings](image3)
 
These museums offer a unique glimpse into Bergen's rich history and cultural heritage, allowing visitors to experience and learn about the city's past in an immersive and engaging way.

### Benefits of Level-2 in the System

OBS provides a highly reliable storage system, and one of the key benefits of this reliability is its **Five-level reliability architecture**.

#### What is Level-2 in the System?
Level-2 in the system refers to the servers. 

#### Benefits of Level-2
The servers in OBS are designed with redundancy in mind, providing a high level of reliability. One of the key benefits of level-2 is **Detection of FRUs (Faulty or Removed Units)**. This means that if a server or a component within a server fails, the system can automatically detect and replace it, minimizing downtime and ensuring data availability.

Here is the image that describes level-2 in the system:
 
![Detection of FRUs](image3)

The answer is: Detection of FRUs

According to the guide, it is recommended to load the dishwasher in a specific way to ensure optimal washing quality. Here is a detailed explanation with supporting images:

To ensure optimal washing quality, it is advised to load the dishwasher as shown in the figure below![Large and difficult to clean items, such as pots and pans, are placed in the lower basket](image1). This is because the lower basket is designed to handle larger and heavier items, which can be easily clogged by food particles and make the washing process less efficient.

Large items such as pots, pans, lids, serving dishes, and bowls should be placed in the lower basket to avoid blocking the rotation of the top spray arm.![Serve dishes and lids are placed on the side of the racks](image2). This allows for better water circulation and ensures that the dishes are properly cleaned.

The upper basket is designed to hold more delicate and lighter dishware, such as glasses, coffee and tea cups.![Cups, glasses, and mugs are placed in the upper basket](image4). However, it is essential to load them in a way that does not touch each other, as this can cause damage. 

Utensils, such as soup spoons, forks, knives, tea spoons, dessert spoons, serving spoons, serving fork, and gravy ladle, should be stacked securely and placed in a way that the spray arms can rotate freely during washing.![Soup spoons, forks, knives, tea spoons, dessert spoons, serving spoons, serving fork, and gravy ladle are loaded in the lower basket](image2).

Additionally, it is crucial to avoid loading dishes and items of cutlery in a way that blocks the spray arms or hampers the opening of the detergent dispenser. The maximum diameter advised for plates in front of the detergent dispenser is of $19\,\mathsf{c m}$. Overloading the dishwasher is also discouraged, as this can lead to poor washing quality and excessive energy consumption.

By following these guidelines and loading the dishwasher correctly, you can ensure optimal washing quality and extend the lifespan of your appliance.

*Answer*: Load the dishwasher by placing large and difficult to clean items in the lower basket, delicate items in the upper basket, and utensils securely in the lower basket, ensuring that the spray arms can rotate freely during washing.

To summarize, the fees associated with applying for a Student's Pass in Singapore include the replacement fee, processing fee, and issuance fee.

Chengdu has been playing host to various significant events and initiatives. The city was designated a Free Trade Zone in April 2017, inspiring beneficial policies and practices [2]. G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors in Chengdu [![A group photo of G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors in Chengdu](image3)]

The timing of the event was part of the city's growing reputation as a financial hub. Answer: The venue and occasion for the group photo of G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors was Chengdu, China, during the convention held from July 23-24, 2016.

The South Asian Studies Programme at NUS offers degrees by research and dissertation at both the M.A and PhD levels, with fluency in English being essential for all theses [1]. The Programme encourages and supports the use of research materials that draw upon South Asian languages.

Several graduate programmes at FASS offer both coursework and research opportunities. These include the Programme by coursework which leads to a Graduate Diploma, Doctoral or Masters, and the Programme by research which equips students to work at great depth at the frontiers of knowledge creation [3]. The Graduate Research Programme here in FASS falls short of nothing other than to give you that most amazing holistic experience you would ever crave for, and to establish those solid fundamentals that these analyses use [7].

The Programme by coursework, which includes both coursework and a thesis, leads to a Masters or PhD degree [3]. The Department of Japanese Studies offers both Masters and PhD programmes, which require coursework and an original research dissertation [5]. Faculty members at the Department of Japanese Studies specialise in a wide array of disciplines, and graduate students will work closely with specific professor(s) in the area of their research.

Students can choose from a variety of graduate programmes that offer both coursework and research opportunities [6]. For instance, the Department of Economics offers a Graduate Research Programme that enables students to gain a holistic experience and establish solid fundamentals [7].

To adjust the strap size of the smartwatch based on your wrist's circumference, you need to first measure your wrist using the built-in ruler on the watch. Place the watch body in the middle of the back of your wrist, with the edge of the watch's body below the root of the ulnar styloid process. This is ensured by [6].

![Measuring the wrist circumference with the watch](image1)

The center of the watch's face should be on your wrist about two fingers width away from the palm. After measuring your wrist circumference, select a strap and airbag that fits your wrist size, as shown in [2].

![Selecting the size of the strap based on the measurement](image2)

To adjust the strap, unfold the long strap and airbag, and dip a cotton swab in an appropriate amount of detergent and water. Slowly wipe the air filter back and forth 20 times along the shorter side of the watch body, until the air filter is clean, following [1]. This helps ensure the strap is secure and comfortable.

![Cleaning the air filter with a cotton swab](image3)

Fasten the nail buckle to secure the strap in place, as described in [2]. To finish adjusting the strap, fasten the airbag buckle, as shown in [5].

![Fastening the airbag buckle to finish adjusting the strap](image4)

To ensure a proper fit, adjust the strap based on your wrist's circumference, following the measurement guideline provided by the watch. This will provide a comfortable and secure fit for your smartwatch.

![Adjusting the strap based on the wrist circumference](image5)

To answer the question, you need to follow the steps in the provided text quotes, specifically [2], [5], and [6], and use the image quotes to demonstrate the steps involved in adjusting the strap size. The strap size can be adjusted by selecting the correct size based on the measurement, fastening the nail buckle, and securing the airbag buckle. This will ensure a comfortable and accurate fit for your smartwatch.

Answer: 
To adjust the strap size of the smartwatch based on your wrist's circumference, you need to select a strap and airbag that fits your wrist size, fasten the nail buckle, and secure the airbag buckle.

**Quickly Accessing Bluetooth and Wi-Fi Features**

To quickly access and manage Bluetooth and Wi-Fi features on a smartphone using the control panel, follow these steps:

1. Swipe down from the upper right edge of your phone to display the Control Panel. Available devices will be displayed in the Device+ section. You can also touch  to search for nearby devices manually. [1]
2. In the Control Panel, you can manage music playback and switch between audio apps with ease. [2]
3. After opening multiple audio apps, swipe down from the upper right edge of the phone to display the Control Panel, then touch the audio playback card at the top of the Control Panel. The currently and recently used audio apps will be displayed in Audio Control Panel. [3]
4. To transfer the current audio playback to a connected device, swipe down from the upper right edge of your phone to display the Control Panel, touch  or the device icon (such as  $\ntrianglerighteq$  ) in the top right corner of the audio control section at the top, then select the audio device from the connected device list. [5]

**Status Icons Indicating Bluetooth and Wi-Fi Features**

The status icons that indicate Bluetooth and Wi-Fi features are enabled can be seen in the Control Panel:

* For Bluetooth:

	+  : Bluetooth device connected
	+  : Bluetooth device connected and has battery status

Tsinghua University has many useful amenities available on campus, including four supermarkets that stock all essential items. Payment at these supermarkets can be made through cash, WeChat, Alipay, or student IC card. As shown in![Opening hours of on-campus supermarkets and markets](image7), the opening hours of these on-campus supermarkets and markets vary.

One of the on-campus supermarkets, Zhaolanyuan Supermarket, is located in the Zhaolanyuan area and has the following opening hours: Monday to Sunday, 8:30am – 5:30pm [10]. This is slightly different from the opening hours of the other on-campus supermarkets.

![Opening hours of Zhaolanyuan Supermarket](image4) is not provided, but another on-campus supermarket, Tmall campus - Zijing store, has the following opening hours: Monday to Sunday, 8:30am - 11:30pm [6]. Tmall campus - Qingfen store and Tmall campus - Guanchou store also have similar opening hours.

![Opening hours of Tmall campus stores](image6) shows the opening hours of the three Tmall campus stores on campus.

For comparison, off-campus supermarkets in the Wudaokou area have the following opening hours: Monday to Sunday, 9:00am - 9:00pm, as shown in![Opening hours of off-campus supermarkets](image1). Another off-campus supermarket, Carrefour, is located in the Zhongguancun area and has the following opening hours: Monday to Sunday, 8:30am - 10:00pm [2]. These opening hours are different from those of the on-campus supermarkets and markets.

To check the departure status of each shuttle route, you can download the “Tsinghua Campus Bus” mobile APP by scanning the QR code or applet code below [2].

Answer: The on-campus supermarkets and markets at Tsinghua University have varying opening hours, ranging from 8:30am - 5:30pm to 8:30am - 11:30pm, while off-campus supermarkets in the Wudaokou area have consistent opening hours of 9:00am - 9:00pm.

**Emergency Medical Assistance**
If you're facing a medical emergency, proceed to the nearest government hospital, such as Ng Teng Fong General Hospital, which is located at![Ng Teng Fong General Hospital](image1). You can contact them at (65) 6716 2000 or email enquiries @juronghealth.com.sg. For more information, visit their website at www.ntfgh.com.sg. [3]

**Student Support Services**
NTU students can seek help from SAO-Student Support, located on level 4 of the Student Services Centre. You can reach them at (65) 6790 6823 (during office hours) or (65) 6790 5200 (24-hour Campus Security Hotline). Email them at SAO-Studentsupport@ntu.edu.sg. [2]

**Accessible Education Unit**
For students with special needs and disabilities, the Accessible Education Unit (AEU) is available to provide professional guidance and advice. You can email them at aeu@ntu.edu.sg. [9]

**Medical Service on Campus**
The Medical Service on campus is operated by Fullerton Healthcare Group, providing general outpatient medical and dental treatment, laboratory and X-ray investigation, as well as minor surgery. They also provide immunization and travel medical advice. [7]

**Student Wellbeing Centre**
The Student Wellbeing Centre is available to all students for professional counselling, with a team of registered counsellors experienced in helping students with various issues. [8]

**Government/Restructured Hospitals**
For a comprehensive list of government/restructured hospitals in Singapore, visit the following websites:![Singapore Government/Restructured Hospitals Website](image4).

**Outpatient Specialist Care**
Important: Outpatient specialist care will only be reimbursed if the specialist is referred by Fullerton Healthcare @ NTU or the A&E department of a government/restructured hospital. [4]

**Matriculation and Reimbursement**
Eligible students can seek reimbursement under the Group Hospitalisation and Surgical Insurance (GHSI) scheme for hospitalisation fees incurred in Singapore government/restructured hospitals. The insurance company will review and determine the reimbursed amount based on the scheme’s terms and conditions. [1]

**Answer**
NTU students can access various medical assistance and support services, including emergency medical assistance, student support services, accessible education unit, medical service on campus, student wellbeing centre, government/restructured hospitals, and outpatient specialist care.

**Seeking Medical Assistance and Support Services at NTU**
NTU has a range of medical assistance and support services available to its students. According to [7], the Student Wellbeing Centre offers professional counselling services for students, and it can be accessed through an appointment made at [www.ntu.edu.sg/student wellbeing/appointment](http://www.ntu.edu.sg/student wellbeing/appointment) or by calling (65) 6790 4462 during office hours. 

Additionally, students can visit the Student Wellbeing Centre located at University Health Service, #02-01, 36 Nanyang Avenue. Consultation is free of charge for students and held in strict confidence.

For medical services on campus, [9] states that the Medical Service is operated by Fullerton Healthcare Group, providing general outpatient medical and dental treatment, laboratory and X-ray investigation, as well as minor surgery. They also provide immunisation and travel medical advice.

If students require insurance, NTU has two insurance schemes - Group Hospitalisation and Surgical Insurance and the Group Personal Accident Insurance - to help eligible students meet basic medical costs, as mentioned in [2].

Students can also access private clinics near NTU, such as those listed on [www.singhealth.com.sg/Patient Care/GP/Pages/Home.aspx](http://www.singhealth.com.sg/Patient Care/GP/Pages/Home.aspx), or visit hospitals such as those listed in `![Hospitals near NTU](image1)`.


**Support Services and Counselling**
For students with special needs, the Accessible Education Unit can be contacted at [aeu@ntu.edu.sg](mailto:aeu@ntu.edu.sg). The Student Wellbeing Centre also administers a peer support network called the ‘Peer Helping Programme’, where student volunteers are trained to befriend and support students with emotional and/or psychological issues, as mentioned in [10].

Students can find more information about the programme by calling or emailing the Student Wellbeing Centre at [student wellbeing@ntu.edu.sg](mailto:student wellbeing@ntu.edu.sg).

**Contact Information**
The SAO-Student Support office is located on level 4 of the Student Services Centre, and students can contact them at [SAO-Studentsupport@ntu.edu.sg](mailto:SAO-Studentsupport@ntu.edu.sg) or by calling (65) 6790 6823 during office hours. Students can also contact the JurongHealth Centre at (65) 6716 2000 or [enquiries @juronghealth.com.sg](mailto:enquiries@juronghealth.com.sg).

Answer: Students can seek medical assistance and support services at NTU by visiting the Student Wellbeing Centre, contacting the Accessible Education Unit, or accessing private clinics and hospitals near campus.

To properly measure your wrist circumference for selecting a strap, you should follow these steps:

According to the instructions, ensure that you are wearing your device correctly [6]. This includes placing the watch body in the middle of the back of your wrist, with the edge of the watch's body below the root of the ulnar styloid process [2]. The center of the watch's face should be on your wrist about two fingers width away from the palm.

Before taking the measurement, you can scan the QR code on the device to view the guide on how to measure the wrist circumference. As shown in![Previous data](image2)
You should then press the Up button and select Blood pressure from the app list. Next, select a range on the wrist circumference settings screen and follow the prompts [6]. Once you are set up, hold the elbow of the arm being measured steady and relax your palm [6].

 Measure the wrist circumference by placing the end of the ruler that comes with the watch through the buckle on the head, at a position that is about the width of two fingers away from the bottom of your palm [5]. Pull the ruler until it touches your arm, but don't pull it too tightly, and record the position indicated by the arrow [7].

According to the instructions, it is crucial to measure the wrist circumference accurately to select the right strap size. 

To answer the question: 
To properly measure your wrist circumference for selecting a strap, you should place the watch body correctly on your wrist, hold your arm steady, and measure the circumference using the ruler provided with the watch.

To connect to another Mac using the Migration Assistant, follow these steps:

First, on the Mac you want to transfer information to (the new MacBook Air), follow the onscreen instructions until you get to the "Do You Already Own a Mac?" screen. Select "from another Mac" as the source of the information you want to transfer. On the next screen, choose your wireless network, and then click Continue.![Connect To Your Other Mac](image2)

On the other Mac (the source of the information), open Migration Assistant (located in /Applications/Utilities/), and then click Continue.![Setup software](image1) Insert the Mac OS X Install Disc 1 that came with your MacBook Air to install the DVD or CD Sharing Setup, which includes software for DVD or CD Sharing, Migration Assistant, and Remote Install Mac OS X. 

Next, on the other Mac, double-click the DVD or CD Sharing Setup package on the Mac OS X Install Disc 1. If the other computer is a Windows computer, choose "DVD or CD Sharing" from the Install Assistant that starts automatically.![Setup software](image1)

When you are prompted for a migration method, select "To another Mac", and then click Continue.![Migration Setup](image4) On the new MacBook Air, when you see the Connect To Your Other Mac screen with a passcode displayed, enter the passcode in Migration Assistant on the other Mac. 

Finally, on the new MacBook Air, select "from another Mac" as the source of the information you want to transfer, choose your wireless network, and then click Continue. The other Mac will then prompt you to enter the passcode, which is 640256. If this isn’t the correct Mac, click Show All to see a list of detected computers. Select the correct Mac and click Continue.![Network Setup](image3)

The necessary steps to connect to another Mac using the Migration Assistant are: 

1.  Open Migration Assistant on both Macs.
2.  Insert the Mac OS X Install Disc 1 on the source Mac and install the DVD or CD Sharing Setup.
3.  Double-click the DVD or CD Sharing Setup package on the source Mac.
4.  Enter the passcode on the new MacBook Air and the source Mac.
5.  Select "To another Mac" as the migration method on the source Mac.
6.  Follow the onscreen instructions on both Macs to complete the migration process.

The datasheet of the 8751H is updated from several other datasheets (MCS-51 Controllers, 8051AHP, 8751BH, 8751BHEXPRESS, 8752BH, and 8752BHEXPRESS).

The 8751H is an EPROM version of the 8051AH, with 4 Kbytes of electrically programmable ROM that can be erased with ultraviolet light. It has a Program Memory Security bit that can be used to protect the EEPROM against unauthorized readout. The 8751H-8 is identical to the 8751H but only operates up to 8 MHz.

The datasheet warns that if the voltage on a pin exceeds the test condition, the voltage on an output pin may exceed the related specification. Pins are not guaranteed to sink current greater than the listed test conditions.

The 875 x BH can be programmed using the Quick Pulse Programming Algorithm for microcontrollers. The features of the new programming method are lower Vpp (12.75 volts as compared to 21 volts) and a shorter programming pulse.

The EA/VPP in must not be allowed to go above the maximum specified VPP level of 21.5V for any amount of time. Even a narrow glitch above that voltage level can cause permanent damage to the device.

The 8031AH/8051 A Hand 8032 AH/8052 AH devices are manufactured on P 414.1, an H MOS ll process. The 8751H/8751H-8 devices are manufactured on P 421.X, an HMOS-E process. The 8751BH and 8752 BH devices are manufactured on P 422.

Capacitive loading on Ports 0 and 2 may cause spurious noise pulses to be superimposed on the Vous of ALE/PROG and Ports 1 and 3.

Maximum IOL per port pin: 10 mA
Maximum IOL per 8-bit port - Port 0: 26mA
Ports 1, 2, and 3: 15mA
Aovimiim tatal Iou for all other pins: 71mA

 Maximum IOL per port pin: 10 mA

As a new student at NTU, you have several options for setting up housing and banking services.

To set up housing, please refer to your offer email for information on the collection of your room key. You can also check-in to your housing and register with SAO-Student Support.![Registration Process](image2)
For further enquiries on housing matters, please contact the Office of Housing and Auxiliary Services (HAS) via email [has-ug@ntu.edu.sg](mailto:has-ug@ntu.edu.sg) for undergraduate students, [has-pg@ntu.edu.sg](mailto:has-pg@ntu.edu.sg) for graduate students, or [has-exch@ntu.edu.sg](mailto:has-exch@ntu.edu.sg) for exchange students.![Housing Enquiry Contact](image1)
You can also visit www.ntu.edu.sg/has for more information on campus and off-campus housing.![HAS Website](image3)

For banking services, you can open an account with the bank of your choice in Singapore. The banks offer a wide range of services and have different types of saving accounts.![Banking Options](image3)
Some of the banks available in Singapore include DBS, OCBC, POSB, and UOB. You can contact them directly or visit their website to determine their requirement for opening and maintaining an account.![List of Banks](image3)
Additionally, you can purchase a Singapore mobile line with M1, SingTel, or StarHub.![Mobile Service Providers](image4)

Once you have settled into your housing, you can register with SAO-Student Support during office hours to complete the registration procedures and be briefed on the procedures to complete the Student’s Pass formalities.![Registration Process](image2)
Please bring along your passport, embarkation card, Letter of Admission/Enrolment, and receipts for any NTU’s Miscellaneous Fee payment.![Required Documents](image5)

If you have any questions after reading through this guidebook, please contact Student Support at Student Affairs Office via email at SAO-student support@ntu.edu.sg or call on us at Student Services Centre, Level 4.

During a workout, you can perform the following functions with the watch's buttons:

You can press and hold the Up button to end a workout session [5]. You can press and hold the Down button to finish the workout [5].

![Switch screen during workout](image5)
 
There are 5 distinct button functions during a workout:

1. Pause or end the running course
2. Lock the screen
3. Adjust the volume for prompts during the workout
4. Switch between screens
5. Finish the workout

In conclusion, the NMRC Dining Out event is a celebration of Navy Medicine research and development, highlighting the significant contributions of the Navy to the field. The event showcases the achievements of Navy Medicine, inspires junior officers to take on leadership roles, and honors the sacrifices made by those who have served in the Navy.

NAMRU-3‟s contributions to medical and scientific research are extensive, as demonstrated by [1] their train-the-trainer program, which provided training for 160 Afghan scientists and technicians on laboratory operations, diagnostic procedures, and ethics in research and management. This program is a comprehensive effort to enhance the capacity of Afghan laboratories, as seen in [2] with the establishment of five hospital laboratories and virology, bacteriology, and serology laboratories within the Central Public Health Laboratory (CPHL).

![Training of Afghan scientists and technicians](image1)

NAMRU-3 also assessed the capacity and capability of laboratory staff and facilities in Afghanistan, focusing on the CPHL in Kabul, as stated in [3]. This engagement was the initial step in building a robust medical research infrastructure in the region.

![Central Public Health Laboratory in Kabul](image2)

The Naval Submarine Medical Research Laboratory (NSMRL) contributes to medical and scientific research by focusing on operational medicine, specifically for the submarine force and human factors within. According to [4], NSMRL conducts medical, psychological, and human performance research, provides independent reviews of human systems-related projects, and develops new concepts for the submarine force.

![NSMRL hyperbaric chamber with external hatch](image3)

This unique chamber allows for prolonged studies of mission profiles that transition from depth to altitude and vice versa. NSMRU-3 and NSMRL's missions align with U.S. military operations by enhancing the efficiency and synergy in biodefense and disease surveillance efforts, as stated in [8].

![NSMRL researchers working in the hyperbaric chamber](image4)

Furthermore, NAMRU-3 has conducted several workshops to train laboratory and administrative staff on proper laboratory procedures, inventory management, quality control, and standard operating procedures, as seen in [10]. These efforts demonstrate the commitment of NAMRU-3 and NSMRL to building a robust medical research infrastructure that supports U.S. military operations.

![NAMRU-3 researchers conducting a workshop](image5)

In conclusion, the contributions of NAMRU-3 and NSMRL to medical and scientific research are significant, and their missions align with U.S. military operations by enhancing biodefense and disease surveillance efforts, supporting the development of a robust medical research infrastructure, and conducting critical research in operational medicine.

The U.S. Naval Medical Research Units, such as NAMRU-3, play a crucial role in supporting both military personnel and local communities across different regions through various activities. 

As seen in [1], NAMRU-3 collaborates with the Navy Entomology Center of Excellence (NECE) to spray insecticides for all base housing, combining it with surveillance and geospacial mapping to determine the distribution of malaria-transmitting mosquitoes. This effort has successfully reduced malaria infections among U.S. troops, illustrating the effectiveness of a force health protection policy employing both environmental vector controls and anti-malarial prophylaxis.

Furthermore, [2] highlights NAMRU-3's significant role in medical research capacity building in Liberia, which is recovering from a brutal 14-year civil war. This effort demonstrates the Unit's commitment to supporting local communities in need.

Moreover, [3] and [4] show the development of the Patient Condition Occurrence Frequency (PCOF) tool by the Expeditionary Medicine Modeling, Simulation, and Analysis group at the Naval Health Research Center (NHRC). This tool generates tables that show the occurrence probabilities of disease and injury types, enabling the military medical planning community to develop accurate patient streams used in healthcare simulations.

In addition, [5] and [7] illustrate the collaboration between Navy biomedical researchers and the Liberian Institute of Biomedical Research (LIBR) on disease vector surveillance, detection of vector-borne viral pathogens such as malaria, and vector control. These projects enable Liberia to independently expand vector-borne disease surveillance and detection capabilities, benefiting both the Liberian Armed Forces and the entire population.

Also, [6] shows the Rickettsia Diseases Research Program's mission to assess the risk of rickettsia diseases to military and civilian personnel worldwide, and [10] highlights the program's training efforts for individuals involved in regions endemic to rickettsia diseases.

![Collaboration between U.S. Naval Medical Research Units and local communities](image1)
As seen in the image, the collaboration between U.S. Naval Medical Research Units and local communities is a crucial aspect of their activities.

The PCOF tool plays a crucial role in military operations by providing a repeatable, organized, and robust estimating method for medical mission planning.![PCOF tool enables robust estimating method](image1)
This tool helps planners to move beyond anecdotal and rule-of-thumb planning estimates, enabling them to develop patient streams used in healthcare simulations. [9]
The PCOF tool generates tables that show the occurrence probabilities of disease and injury types typically sustained in a contingency by a population at risk.![PCOF tables for wounded in action and nonbattle injuries](image2)
These tables exist within casualty categories of wounded in action, nonbattle injuries, disease, and outpatient visits for a given combat or noncombat scenario throughout the range of military operations (ROMO). [10]
The PCOF tool is essential for military medical planning, as it provides a functional and accurate means of estimating PCOFs, which are necessary for healthcare simulations.![Effective, accurate, and repeatable method of generating PCOF estimates](image3)
This tool has the potential to dramatically enhance medical mission planning, allowing planners to tailor baselined, mission-centric PCOF data to more precisely fit the anticipated mission.![Baselined, mission-centric PCOF data](image4)
The PCOF tool is also used to inform decision makers on the types of patient conditions to expect during a contingency, enabling them to make more informed decisions.![Patient Condition Occurrence Frequency tool](image5)
Overall, the PCOF tool is a critical component of military medical planning, enabling planners to develop more accurate and effective plans for medical missions.

The PCOF tool is used to develop patient streams used in healthcare simulations, which are necessary for estimating medical requirements during a contingency. [10]
Using the PCOF tool, planners can employ baselined, mission-centric PCOF data and tailor it to more precisely fit the anticipated mission, helping inform decision makers on the types of patient conditions to expect. [6]
The PCOF tool provides an effective, accurate, and repeatable method of generating PCOF estimates using standardized and documented means of adjusting baseline distributions. [9]

The answer to the question is: The Patient Condition Occurrence Frequency (PCOF) tool plays a crucial role in military operations by providing a repeatable, organized, and robust estimating method for medical mission planning, enabling planners to develop patient streams used in healthcare simulations and informing decision makers on the types of patient conditions to expect during a contingency.

The USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership 2012 and the DoD Bone Marrow Program are two separate initiatives with distinct objectives and activities. Here's a summary of their main goals and accomplishments.

![Providing medical care and conducting humanitarian projects](image1.jpg)

The USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership 2012 aimed to provide medical care and conduct humanitarian projects in four host nations: Indonesia, the Philippines, Vietnam, and Cambodia. During the 56-day mission, the crew treated over 49,000 patients, performed over 900 surgeries, and conducted various non-medical projects. The partnership demonstrated the US military's commitment to humanitarian assistance and disaster response.

In contrast, the DoD Bone Marrow Program focuses on marrow donation and transplantation for patients with potentially fatal diseases. The program relies on voluntary donors, and since 2010, over 42,000 service members, family members, and DoD employees have registered to become potential marrow donors. Of these, over 5,200 have donated marrow for patients in need.

While both initiatives have significant humanitarian impact, they differ in their primary objectives and activities. The USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership 2012 concentrated on providing medical care and conducting humanitarian projects, whereas the DoD Bone Marrow Program focuses on marrow donation and transplantation.

The [3] C.W. Bill Young DoD Marrow Donor Program is operated by the Navy and Georgetown University, and it plays a crucial role in matching potential donors with patients in need of marrow transplants. This program relies on voluntary donors and has had a significant impact on patients with potentially fatal diseases.

In [4], the USNS Mercy sailed to the Pacific Partnership 2012, where it provided medical care and conducted humanitarian projects. The crew's efforts demonstrated the US military's commitment to humanitarian assistance and disaster response.

The [5] project combining insecticide spraying for all base housing with surveillance and geospatial mapping to determine the distribution of malaria-transmitting mosquitoes has been successful in reducing malaria infections among U.S. troops.

The [6] Pacific Partnership 2012 provided medical care and conducted humanitarian projects in four host nations, treating over 49,000 patients and performing over 900 surgeries.

The [7] Joint Pandemic Working Group (JPG) was established to update and formulate the CONPLAN to prepare for, respond to, and mitigate a pandemic outbreak of influenza or other infectious disease of operational significance.

The [8] basewide drive to register service members with the C.W. Bill Young Department of Defense Marrow Donor Program was conducted at Marine Corps Base Hawaii.

The [9] C.W. Bill Young DoD Marrow Donor Program has registered over 42,000 service members, family members, and DoD employees as potential marrow donors, with over 5,200 having donated marrow for patients in need.

**Answer:** The main objectives of the USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership 2012 were to provide medical care and conduct humanitarian projects, while the DoD Bone Marrow Program focused on marrow donation and transplantation for patients with potentially fatal diseases.

### NAMRU-3 and USNS Mercy Collaboration: Improving Medical Practices in 2012
#### Comprehensive Training Efforts
NAMRU-3 played a pivotal role in enhancing medical practices through its training programs in 2012. The organization conducted laboratory assessments to identify gaps in knowledge and skills, which led to the development of a comprehensive training plan. This plan included nine modules covering parasitology, bacteriology, bioscience facility management, clinical epidemiology, microbiomedical equipment repair, laboratory quality management systems, serology, molecular biology, and virology.

![NAMRU-3 Training Modules](image1)
#### Training in Afghanistan
In 2011, NAMRU-3 had already provided training to 160 Afghan scientists and technicians on laboratory operations, diagnostic procedures, and ethics in research and management. This experience undoubtedly contributed to the development of the 2012 training plan.

![Training in Afghanistan](image2)
#### USNS Mercy and NAMRU-3 Partnership
Cmdr. Charmagne Beckett, a Naval Medical Research Center (NMRC) physician researcher, embarked on the USNS Mercy for the Pacific Partnership 2012 mission. Beckett presented ten SMEE lectures and advised host nation healthcare personnel on infection control, disease outbreak response, and specific disease management.

![USNS Mercy and NAMRU-3 Collaboration](image3)
#### Support in Host Nations
The USNS Mercy and its team conducted medical missions in four host nations: Indonesia, the Philippines, Vietnam, and Cambodia. During this time, they provided medical care to over 49,000 patients, including general adult and pediatric medical care, dental and vision screenings, and surgeries. Beckett's knowledge of Navy research capabilities helped in the confirmation of norovirus as the cause of a shipboard outbreak of gastroenteritis.

![Medical Missions in Host Nations](image4)
#### Conclusion
The collaboration between NAMRU-3 and the USNS Mercy significantly improved medical practices in 2012. Through comprehensive training and humanitarian efforts, they strengthened the capacity of healthcare personnel in various countries. This partnership exemplifies the potential for collaboration in advancing medical knowledge and improving healthcare globally.

[1] and [6] from the provided text quotes emphasize the role of NAMRU-3 and Cmdr. Beckett in developing and implementing training programs. [7] highlights the medical missions conducted by the USNS Mercy in various host nations. [4] and [5] illustrate the training efforts of NAMRU-3.

NAMRU-3 has contributed significantly to international health and defense efforts through various military-to-military engagements and capacity building programs. For instance, they have collaborated with the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) on vector control training efforts, as depicted in [1].

**![Capacity building in Liberia](image1)**
This collaboration has been a vital part of Liberia's recovery from a brutal 14-year civil war, with NAMRU-3 playing a crucial role in medical research capacity building in the country [10]. 

Additionally, NAMRU-3 has worked closely with the Navy Entomology Center of Excellence (NECE) to implement an insecticide spraying program for all base housing in Liberia, which has resulted in a significant reduction in malaria infections among U.S. troops [4]. This demonstrates the effectiveness of a force health protection policy employing both environmental vector controls and anti-malarial prophylaxis.

**![Insecticide spraying in Liberia](image2)**
The Minister of Health and Social Welfare of Liberia has expressed high praise for NAMRU-3's capacity building engagements in the country, highlighting the importance of the collaboration in restoring Liberia's capabilities in the healthcare sector [3]. 

Furthermore, the Director of LIBR has acknowledged the significant impact of NAMRU-3's collaboration, stating, “The collaboration with NAMRU-3 is helping to restore many of the capabilities that LIBR had before the war” [5].

**![Meeting with key collaborators](image3)**
In another effort, NAMRU-3 has developed the Patient Condition Occurrence Frequency (PCOF) tool, which is a joint patient occurrence generating application. This tool was presented to the Force Health Protection and Readiness, Strategic Analysis Working Group Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense, Health Affairs, as part of the verification, validation, and accreditation (VV&A) plan for service acceptance [2].

**![PCOF tool development](image4)**
These efforts not only support U.S. war fighters but also contribute to the development of Liberia's healthcare infrastructure, as emphasized by Capt. Buhari Oyofo, NAMRU-3 commanding officer: “Our projects in Liberia directly support our war fighters, and we also need to leave the knowledge and tools behind so they can continue to support themselves once we’re done” [9].

**![Capt. Buhari Oyofo](image5)**
In summary, NAMRU-3's contributions to international health and defense efforts are evident in their capacity building programs, vector control training, and the development of the PCOF tool, all of which aim to enhance the healthcare capabilities of Liberia and support U.S. war fighters.

Answer: NAMRU-3 units contribute to international health and defense efforts by engaging in capacity building programs, vector control training, and the development of tools that support force health protection policies.
